comment: The assertion that students' seeing the impact of a hunger strike on Peyrin was a violation of Regents Policy 2301 is a dangerous interpretation of that policy. Furthermore, Peyrin's comments regarding Palestine were made following class. The action against Peyrin seems aimed at limiting free speech and sanctioning a highly visible pro-Palestine voice in campus. Our job as STEM faculty is to encourage our colleagues and students to reckon with the ethical implications of science and technology. I see Peyrin's actions as doing just that.

comment: If there was ever a clear line to be drawn for what 'ethical' technology is, it is whether or not the tech supports genocide. In my time at Berkeley (CS + ISF BA, EECS MS), I learned about the IBM punch cards that enabled the holocaust, and it was ok for my professors to say "never again should our discipline be complicit in something like this." This was the absolute bare minimum of our "tech ethics" training. The AI and computing technologies being used to surveil Palestinians and mark them for death are most certainly built upon Berkeley innovations in computer vision, databases, etc. At the very least, then, now is the time for us computer scientists to recognize the evil our contributions are being used for and to stand against it. It is damning that the administration would choose to punish and silence the member of CS faculty with the greatest moral clarity around this, and I'm deeply ashamed of my alma mater. (And I'm sure when I visit campus in 30 years I'll be able to drop in on the "Free Palestine" Cafe, where there'll be a plaque honoring Peyrin's bravery so the administration can reap the reputational rewards of having always been against genocide once it is again politically convenient.)

comment: The suppression of Palestine advocacy on campuses is a litmus test for the integrity of higher education itself. If we cannot defend the right to oppose genocide without professional retaliation, we have already lost the core values universities claim to uphold.
